feed.title: zTree Repository for the Behavioral Sciences
feed.subtitle: A library of zTree files, tutorials and related tools.

entry.title: Sliders
entry.content:
Download raw text Download ztt View image

Description

  1. Author: David Clarance
  2. Purpose: Sliders useful for representing absolute scales or distributional shares.
  3. Version: 3.6.6

Documentation

Using the text file

To use the zTree text file, click the Download text button above. It will take you to a text file. Right click and “Save As” to your computer. In zTree use File > Import to read the file in. Please note that there are compatibility issues across different zTree versions so make you have a version that’s the same or later than the version the file was written in.

Important variables in the zTree file

numberL - Distance from the left edge of the scale to the position of the pointer.

numberR - Distance from the right edge of the scale to the position of the pointer.
entry.summary: Touch screen sliders with dynamic position display

entry.title: Randomizing screens within a stage
entry.content:
Download raw text Download ztt View image

Description

  1. Author: David Clarance. See original attribution and details below.
  2. Purpose: Randomize screens within a stage. Useful if you want to randomize the order of decisios made by participants.
  3. Version: 3.6.6

Documentation

Attribution and details

This file derives from drawing numbers generated in a randomized array. The randomized array method is by no means mine. It derives from the Fisher-Yater shuffle algorithm. I first saw it used by Anwar A. Ruff and he provides code and a really nice, detailed explanation here. Anwar has a great set of tools for running experiments, do check out his github page.

Using the text file

To use the zTree text file, click the Download text button above. It will take you to a text file. Right click and “Save As” to your computer. In zTree use File > Import to read the file in. Please note that there are compatibility issues across different zTree versions so make you have a version that’s the same or later than the version the file was written in.

Important variables in the zTree file

order[n] - Array that is randomized. n gives the length of the array.

game_counter - Counter variable that cycles through screens within a stage.
entry.summary: Generate random orders of screens within a stage

entry.title: Creating randomized arrays
entry.content:
Download raw text Download ztt View image

Description

  1. Author: David Clarance. See original attribution and details below.
  2. Purpose: Generate an array with randomized numbers drawn without replacement from a distribution.
  3. Version: 3.6.6

Documentation

Attribution and details

This method is by no means mine. It derives from the Fisher-Yater shuffle algorithm. I first saw it used by Anwar A. Ruff and he provides code and a really nice, detailed explanation here. Anwar has a great set of tools for running experiments, do check out his github page.

Using the text file

To use the zTree text file, click the Download text button above. It will take you to a text file. Right click and “Save As” to your computer. In zTree use File > Import to read the file in. Please note that there are compatibility issues across different zTree versions so make you have a version that’s the same or later than the version the file was written in.

Important variables in the zTree file

order[n] - Array that is randomized. n gives the length of the array.
entry.summary: Create a array with randomized numbers drawn without replacement

entry.title: Touch screen number pad
entry.content:
Download raw text Download ztt View image

Description

  1. Author: Chaning Jang
  2. Purpose: An on-screen number pad to enable individuals who have never used a keyboard to enter numbers.
  3. Version: 3.6.6

Documentation

Using the text file

To use the zTree text file, click the Download text button above. It will take you to a text file. Right click and “Save As” to your computer. In zTree use File > Import to read the file in. Please note that there are compatibility issues across different zTree versions so make you have a version that’s the same or later than the version the file was written in.

Important variables in the zTree file

number - Respondent input is stored in this variable.
entry.summary: Number pad with Clear button to enable individuals who have never used a keyboard before to enter numbers

entry.title: zTree Code Template
entry.content:
Download code

Description

  1. Author: Sample author
  2. Purpose: Why is this file useful?
  3. Version: What version of zTree was the file created with?
  4. Notes: Add additional notes if necessary - original authors, ztree background specificiations etc.

Figures

Add link to figures folder here if useful. Screenshots of code snippets are also acceptable.

Documentation

You can place additional notes on how to use the file. All documentation must contain the section below

Using this file

To use this zTree file, click the Download button above. It will take you to a text file. Right click and “Save As” to your computer. In zTree use File > Import to read the file in. Please note that there are compatibility issues across different zTree versions so make you have a version that’s the same or later than the version the file was written in.

Additional instructions

Place additional instructions here.
entry.summary: A standardized format to upload a new code snippet

entry.title: MathJax Example
entry.content:
MathJax is a simple way of including Tex/LaTex/MathML based mathematics in HTML webpages. To get up and running you need to include the MathJax script in the header of your github pages page, and then write some maths. For LaTex, there are two delimiters you need to know about, one for block or displayed mathematics \[ ... \], and the other for inline mathematics \( ... \).

Usage

To enable MathJax support be sure Kramdown is your Markdown flavor of choice and MathJax is set to true in your _config.yml file.

markdown: kramdown
mathjax: true

Here is an example MathJax inline rendering \\( 1/x^{2} \\), and here is a block rendering: 
\\[ \frac{1}{n^{2}} \\]

Here is an example MathJax inline rendering \( 1/x^{2} \), and here is a block rendering: \[ \frac{1}{n^{2}} \]

The only thing to look out for is the escaping of the backslash when using markdown, so the delimiters become \\[ ... \\] and \\( ... \\) for inline and block maths respectively.
entry.summary: MathJax is a simple way of including Tex/LaTex/MathML based mathematics in HTML webpages. To get up and running you need to include the MathJax script in the header of your github pages page, and then write some maths. For LaTex, there are two delimiters you need to know about, one for block or displayed mathematics \[ ... \], and the other for inline mathematics \( ... \).

entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory - edit this post and re-build (or run with the -w switch) to see your changes! To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention: YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext.

Sample Heading

Sample Heading 2

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory - edit this post and re-build (or run with the -w switch) to see your changes! To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention: YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext.
